awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Evolution of the extended floral phenotype
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. The Fellow will investigate the effect of biotic interactions on the expression and evolution of floral traits. Pollinators are a significant force of selection on floral traits, including size, color, and scent. Floral tissues frequently harbor a diversity of microbes, however, which impact cues important for pollinator attraction, with consequences for host reproduction. Despite the potential for such effects, it remains unclear whether microbes can modify pollinator-mediated selection on floral traits. After manipulating interactions among a flowering host, pollinator, and microbes the Fellow will use chemical and molecular techniques to assess the strength and direction of selection exerted on floral traits by these biotic interactions. Such research will advance pollination biology and inform understanding of factors promoting floral diversification. The Fellow will also collaborate with local institutions and programs to broaden participation of underrepresented groups at the middle school, high school, and undergraduate levels through providing opportunities for learning and research. 

The Fellow will test the hypothesis that floral microbes and pollinators jointly shape selection on floral phenotype. Using fast-cycling Brassica rapa plants and an experimental evolution framework, the Fellow will manipulate interactions among host plant, bumble bee (Bombus impatiens), bacterium (Bacillus subtilis), and/or yeast (Metschnikowia reukaufii) to dissect biotic drivers of floral phenotypic evolution. More specifically, the Fellow will address the following three objectives: 1) examination of interactive effects of microbes and pollinators on floral evolution, 2) characterization of molecular mechanisms underlying shifts in floral phenotype, and 3) assessment of reciprocal selection on microbial inhabitants of flowers. By considering such eco-evolutionary dynamics among interacting partners, and taking a multi-level selection approach that employs genomic, transcriptomic, and metabolomic approaches, this study will address an important but understudied component of pollination mutualism and the sources of variation upon which natural selection can act. In performing the research, the Fellow will acquire new skills in genomics, transcriptomics, and metabolomics. Finally, middle school, high school, and college students from groups underrepresented in the sciences will be included in the research, with the Fellow also giving guest lectures in plant science courses and at outreach events.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Pollinators select flowers that are most appealing to them based on their size, coloration, and smell to maximize the floral rewards they receive. As a result of pollinator selection, these floral traits evolve in response to the selective pressure incurred by these animals. Floral microbes are an underappreciated aspect of the plant-pollinator mutualism. They are introduced in ot flowers by wind and pollination. After introduction, these microbes consequently modify the floral environment for their own fitness. When present in flowers, these organisms alter the floral bouquet by introducing their own scents into the floral bouquet. As a result of their presence, pollinators are differentially attracted to these flowers. Since floral microbes have been demonstrated to modify pollinator preferences, we sought to understand if the presence of two common floral microbes, a floral yeast (Metschnikowia reukaufii) and bacterium (Bacillus subtilis) along with bumblebee pollination (Bombus impatiens), could influence floral trait evolution and determine if the flowers themselves could select for traits in floral colonists. Plants were either hand or bee pollinated and flowers were treated as uninoculated controls, inoculated with only the bacterium, or co-inoculated with the bacterium and the yeast.

We found that the presence of floral microbes differentially alters floral morphological traits and that these changes were significantly altered if they were selected upon by pollinators. Traits such as pistil, anther and petal length, were significantly longer in bee-pollinated relative to hand pollinated plants. The presence of the yeast and bacterium exasperated these differences. Bacterium inoculated flowers that were bee pollinated had longer petals, anthers, and pistils relative to the other treatment groups.

To assess if alterations in floral quality could shape the evolutionary trajectory of floral colonizing microbes, we assessed how changes in microbial traits would be influenced by alterations in nectar quality. For this work, we placed our floral yeast and bacteria into synthetic nectar mimics with varying concentrations of proteins and nectar metabolites and simulated 8 generations of flowers. Throughout the experiment, we monitored differences in microbial resource use and fitness by quantifying changes in nectar quality and microbial abundance respectively. While there were no differences in microbe fitness across our synthetic nectar backgrounds, we found significant changes in nectar quality depending on if the floral bacteria or yeast grew in the presence of certain compounds for multiple generations.  

Along with the ecological and evolutionary implications of this work, this fellowship provided opportunities for four undergraduate students and a postbaccalaureate scholar to gain hands on research experience. One student completed an honor’s thesis studying how nectar backgrounds influence microbial phenotypic shifts and consequent pollinator visitation rates and she is now pursuing graduate studies in marine biology. With support from this work, four other undergraduate students gained research skills and are also pursuing careers in STEM and we aim to publish our results within the upcoming year.
